member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.CanBeNullAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked element could be null sometimes, so checking for null is required before its usage.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.NotNullAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked element can never be null.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ItemNotNullAttribute
member.summary: Can be applied to symbols of types derived from IEnumerable as well as to symbols of Task and Lazy classes to indicate that the value of a collection item, of the Task.Result property or of the Lazy.Value property can never be null.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ItemCanBeNullAttribute
member.summary: Can be applied to symbols of types derived from IEnumerable as well as to symbols of Task and Lazy classes to indicate that the value of a collection item, of the Task.Result property or of the Lazy.Value property can be null.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.StringFormatMethodAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked method builds string by the format pattern and (optional) arguments. The parameter, which contains the format string, should be given in constructor. The format string should be in -like form.

member.name: M:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.StringFormatMethodAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.param: Specifies which parameter of an annotated method should be treated as the format string

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ValueProviderAttribute
member.summary: Use this annotation to specify a type that contains static or const fields with values for the annotated property/field/parameter. The specified type will be used to improve completion suggestions.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ValueRangeAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the integral value falls into the specified interval. It's allowed to specify multiple non-intersecting intervals. Values of interval boundaries are inclusive.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.NonNegativeValueAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the integral value never falls below zero.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.InvokerParameterNameAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the function argument should be a string literal and match one of the parameters of the caller function. For example, ReSharper annotates the parameter of .

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.NotifyPropertyChangedInvocatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the method is contained in a type that implements System.ComponentModel.INotifyPropertyChanged interface and this method is used to notify that some property value changed.
member.remarks:
The method should be non-static and conform to one of the supported signatures:
NotifyChanged(string)
NotifyChanged(params string[])
NotifyChanged{T}(Expression{Func{T}})
NotifyChanged{T,U}(Expression{Func{T,U}})
SetProperty{T}(ref T, T, string)

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output.
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If the method has a single input parameter, its name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for the method output means that the method doesn't return normally (throws or terminates the process).
Value canbenull is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon. There is no notion of order rows, all rows are checked for applicability and applied per each program state tracked by the analysis engine.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("null <= param:null")] // reverse condition syntax public string GetName(string surname)
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // string.IsNullOrEmpty()
[ContractAnnotation("=> true, result: notnull; => false, result: null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.LocalizationRequiredAttribute
member.summary: Indicates whether the marked element should be localized.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.CannotApplyEqualityOperatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked type (or its derivatives) cannot be compared using '==' or '!=' operators and Equals() should be used instead. However, using '==' or '!=' for comparison with null is always permitted.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.BaseTypeRequiredAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a target attribute, specifies a requirement for any type marked with the target attribute to implement or inherit specific type or types.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.UsedImplicitlyAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked symbol is used implicitly (e.g. via reflection, in external library), so this symbol will not be reported as unused (as well as by other usage inspections).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.MeansImplicitUseAttribute
member.summary: Can be applied to attributes, type parameters, and parameters of a type assignable from . When applied to an attribute, the decorated attribute behaves the same as . When applied to a type parameter or to a parameter of type , indicates that the corresponding type is used implicitly.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags
member.summary: Specify the details of implicitly used symbol when it is marked with or .

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.Access
member.summary: Only entity marked with attribute considered used.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.Assign
member.summary: Indicates implicit assignment to a member.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.InstantiatedWithFixedConstructorSignature
member.summary: Indicates implicit instantiation of a type with fixed constructor signature. That means any unused constructor parameters won't be reported as such.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.InstantiatedNoFixedConstructorSignature
member.summary: Indicates implicit instantiation of a type.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ImplicitUseTargetFlags
member.summary: Specify what is considered to be used implicitly when marked with or .

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ImplicitUseTargetFlags.Members
member.summary: Members of entity marked with attribute are considered used.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ImplicitUseTargetFlags.WithInheritors
member.summary: Inherited entities are considered used.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ImplicitUseTargetFlags.WithMembers
member.summary: Entity marked with attribute and all its members considered used.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.PublicAPIAttribute
member.summary: This attribute is intended to mark publicly available API which should not be removed and so is treated as used.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.InstantHandleAttribute
member.summary: Tells code analysis engine if the parameter is completely handled when the invoked method is on stack. If the parameter is a delegate, indicates that delegate is executed while the method is executed. If the parameter is an enumerable, indicates that it is enumerated while the method is executed.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.PureAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a method does not make any observable state changes. The same as System.Diagnostics.Contracts.PureAttribute.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.MustUseReturnValueAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the return value of the method invocation must be used.
member.remarks:
Methods decorated with this attribute (in contrast to pure methods) might change state, but make no sense without using their return value.
Similarly to , this attribute will help detecting usages of the method when the return value in not used. Additionally, you can optionally specify a custom message, which will be used when showing warnings, e.g. [MustUseReturnValue("Use the return value to...")].

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.ProvidesContextAttribute
member.summary: Indicates the type member or parameter of some type, that should be used instead of all other ways to get the value of that type. This annotation is useful when you have some "context" value evaluated and stored somewhere, meaning that all other ways to get this value must be consolidated with existing one.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.PathReferenceAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a parameter is a path to a file or a folder within a web project. Path can be relative or absolute, starting from web root (~).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.SourceTemplateAttribute
member.summary: An extension method marked with this attribute is processed by code completion as a 'Source Template'. When the extension method is completed over some expression, its source code is automatically expanded like a template at call site.
member.remarks: Template method body can contain valid source code and/or special comments starting with '$'. Text inside these comments is added as source code when the template is applied. Template parameters can be used either as additional method parameters or as identifiers wrapped in two '$' signs. Use the attribute to specify macros for parameters.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.MacroAttribute
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro for a parameter of a source template.
member.remarks: You can apply the attribute on the whole method or on any of its additional parameters. The macro expression is defined in the property. When applied on a method, the target template parameter is defined in the property. To apply the macro silently for the parameter, set the property value = -1.

member.name: P:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Expression
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro that will be executed for a source template parameter when the template is expanded.

member.name: P:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Editable
member.summary: Allows specifying which occurrence of the target parameter becomes editable when the template is deployed.

member.name: P:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Target
member.summary: Identifies the target parameter of a source template if the is applied on a template method.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcActionAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. If applied to a parameter, indicates that the parameter is an MVC action. If applied to a method, the MVC action name is calculated implicitly from the context. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Html.ChildActionExtensions.RenderAction(HtmlHelper, String).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcAreaAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. Indicates that the marked parameter is an MVC area. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Html.ChildActionExtensions.RenderAction(HtmlHelper, String).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcControllerAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. If applied to a parameter, indicates that the parameter is an MVC controller. If applied to a method, the MVC controller name is calculated implicitly from the context. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Html.ChildActionExtensions.RenderAction(HtmlHelper, String, String).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcMasterAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. Indicates that the marked parameter is an MVC Master. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Controller.View(String, String).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcModelTypeAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. Indicates that the marked parameter is an MVC model type. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Controller.View(String, Object).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcPartialViewAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. If applied to a parameter, indicates that the parameter is an MVC partial view. If applied to a method, the MVC partial view name is calculated implicitly from the context. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Html.RenderPartialExtensions.RenderPartial(HtmlHelper, String).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcSuppressViewErrorAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. Allows disabling inspections for MVC views within a class or a method.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcDisplayTemplateAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. Indicates that a parameter is an MVC display template. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Html.DisplayExtensions.DisplayForModel(HtmlHelper, String).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcEditorTemplateAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. Indicates that the marked parameter is an MVC editor template. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Html.EditorExtensions.EditorForModel(HtmlHelper, String).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcTemplateAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. Indicates that the marked parameter is an MVC template. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations.UIHintAttribute(System.String).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcViewAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. If applied to a parameter, indicates that the parameter is an MVC view component. If applied to a method, the MVC view name is calculated implicitly from the context. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Controller.View(Object).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcViewComponentAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. If applied to a parameter, indicates that the parameter is an MVC view component name.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcViewComponentViewAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. If applied to a parameter, indicates that the parameter is an MVC view component view. If applied to a method, the MVC view component view name is default.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AspMvcActionSelectorAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. When applied to a parameter of an attribute, indicates that this parameter is an MVC action name.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.RazorSectionAttribute
member.summary: Razor attribute. Indicates that the marked parameter or method is a Razor section. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.WebPages.WebPageBase.RenderSection(String).

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.CollectionAccessAttribute
member.summary: Indicates how method, constructor invocation, or property access over collection type affects the contents of the collection. Use to specify the access type.
member.remarks: Using this attribute only makes sense if all collection methods are marked with this attribute.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.CollectionAccessType
member.summary: Provides a value for the to define how the collection method invocation affects the contents of the collection.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.CollectionAccessType.None
member.summary: Method does not use or modify content of the collection.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.CollectionAccessType.Read
member.summary: Method only reads content of the collection but does not modify it.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.CollectionAccessType.ModifyExistingContent
member.summary: Method can change content of the collection but does not add new elements.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.CollectionAccessType.UpdatedContent
member.summary: Method can add new elements to the collection.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AssertionMethodAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked method is assertion method, i.e. it halts the control flow if one of the conditions is satisfied. To set the condition, mark one of the parameters with attribute.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AssertionConditionAttribute
member.summary: Indicates the condition parameter of the assertion method. The method itself should be marked by attribute. The mandatory argument of the attribute is the assertion type.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AssertionConditionType
member.summary: Specifies assertion type. If the assertion method argument satisfies the condition, then the execution continues. Otherwise, execution is assumed to be halted.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_TRUE
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to true.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_FALSE
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to false.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_NULL
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to null value.

member.name: F:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_NOT_NULL
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to not null value.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.TerminatesProgramAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked method unconditionally terminates control flow execution. For example, it could unconditionally throw exception.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.LinqTunnelAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that method is pure LINQ method, with postponed enumeration (like Enumerable.Select, .Where). This annotation allows inference of [InstantHandle] annotation for parameters of delegate type by analyzing LINQ method chains.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.NoEnumerationAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that IEnumerable passed as a parameter is not enumerated. Use this annotation to suppress the 'Possible multiple enumeration of IEnumerable' inspection.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.RegexPatternAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked parameter is a regular expression pattern.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.NoReorderAttribute
member.summary: Prevents the Member Reordering feature from tossing members of the marked class.
member.remarks: The attribute must be mentioned in your member reordering patterns.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.XamlItemsControlAttribute
member.summary: XAML attribute. Indicates the type that has ItemsSource property and should be treated as ItemsControl-derived type, to enable inner items DataContext type resolve.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.XamlItemBindingOfItemsControlAttribute
member.summary: XAML attribute. Indicates the property of some BindingBase-derived type, that is used to bind some item of ItemsControl-derived type. This annotation will enable the DataContext type resolve for XAML bindings for such properties.
member.remarks: Property should have the tree ancestor of the ItemsControl type or marked with the attribute.

member.name: T:Notifications.Wpf.Annotations.XamlItemStyleOfItemsControlAttribute
member.summary: XAML attribute. Indicates the property of some Style-derived type, that is used to style items of ItemsControl-derived type. This annotation will enable the DataContext type resolve for XAML bindings for such properties.
member.remarks: Property should have the tree ancestor of the ItemsControl type or marked with the attribute.
